data.title: Richard Attenborough widow Sheila Sim dies, aged 93
data.meta_description: RICHARD ATTENBOROUGH’S wife Sheila Sim has passed away, aged 93, just over a year after the legendary filmmaker’s death in August, 2014.
data.text:
Sim, also known as Lady Attenborough, was tragically diagnosed with dementia three years ago and her death was announced following a performance of The Mousetrap in Nottingham's Theatre Royal last night.

The late actress performed the role of Mollie Ralston in 1952's original stage adaptation of the Agatha Christie classic, beside her husband Attenborough.

The Mousetrap is currently the longest-running play on the West End and has been standing strong on the London stage for over six decades.

Sim’s death was revealed to an audience at the end of the play ahead of the traditional "keep the Mousetrap murderer secret" speech.

Stephen Waley-Cohen, owner-manager of the St Martins Theatre in the West End, where The Mousetrap has run since 1974, said: “Sheila Sim was a delightful and charming lady, very supportive of all of her family and their varied and successful theatrical careers.

"She was always interested in whatever was happening at RADA too, the academy where she and Richard [Attenborough] had first met as students in the 1940s, where he invited me to join the council. Everyone at The Mousetrap was honoured to be able to dedicate yesterday’s performances in London and Nottingham to her memory."

He added: "Nearly 50 years after The Mousetrap opened in 1952, Sheila and Richard helped and encouraged us in the creation of Mousetrap Theatre Projects, which takes thousands of disadvantaged young people to the best of West End theatre every year."

The starlet broke through as one of the country’s most prominent leading lady’s, with a string of successful film and stage productions in the 1940s and 1950s, including School for Spinsters in 1947, Love’s a Funny Thing in 1949 and To Dorothy a Son in 1950.

Sim had reportedly been living at the actors’ retirement home in Denville Hall since her dementia diagnosis in 2013.

The couple’s son, theatre director Michael Attenborough, opened up about his mother’s illness to actor’s bible, The Stage.

He told the magazine: “I’m running their affairs for them now, so there is a lot when I see them that I have to tell and bring them up to speed about. They have been together 70 years now.”

Richard Attenborough requested his ashes be buried with the couple’s daughter and granddaughter, who both died in the 2004 Boxing Day tsunami.

He asked that a a third of his ashes to be “interred in casket together with or alongside” daughter Jane Holland, 49, and granddaughter Lucy, 15, in a vault at the St Mary Magdalene church, Richmond, Surrey.
